newsitem.title: INDIA: India joins Pakistan in mourning singer's death.
newsitem.headline: India joins Pakistan in mourning singer's death.

text.p: India's media and performing artists on Sunday mourned the death of a Pakistani singer who symbolised close cultural relations between two nations usually in the news for diplomatic rows and the wars they have fought.

All leading newspapers carried front-page stories on the death on Saturday of Nusrat Fateh Ali Khan, who fused western rhythms into a mystic, classical style of chorus singing in the subcontinent, called "qawwali".
"It is very unfortunate that I could not sing for such a great music wizard," the Press Trust of India quoted the nation's best known playback singer, Lata Mangeshkar, as saying.
"He not only composed tunes which were like a new breeze to Hindi film music but was a great singer himself," said Mangeskhar.

Khan, died at 49 of a heart attack arising from kidney problems in London one day after the 50th anniversary of secular but largely Hindu India's independence from British rule, which accompanied bloody inter-religious riots in 1947.
Islamic Pakistan, which has fought three wars with India, two of them over disputed Kashmir, marked its 50th anniversary on Thursday.
Khan often spoke of close cultural relations between the two nations, and his Sufi tradition of mystical music that preaches amity between religions.
"He strove to unite the musical legacies of the two countries in the past many years," said an obituary in Indian Express, which carried Khan's death as its lead story.
"It is not just Pakistan's loss, it is the subcontinent's loss, music's loss," Indian lyricist Javed Akhtar was quoted by Pioneer newspaper on Sunday as saying.
He dismissed unconfirmed media statements that Khan had made remarks critical of India. "I don't believe a word of that," said Akhtar, who has worked with Khan.

India saw on its Independence Day the release of a movie, "Aur Pyar Ho Gaya" (And then there was love), for which Khan scored the music. Khan's music and the movie, starring former Miss World Aishwarya Rai, received rave reviews on Sunday.

Khan had also scored a highly successful score for another Indian movie, "Bandit Queen," a biographical work about former woman bandit Phoolan Devi, who surrendered to police in 1983. Devi is now an Indian lawmaker for a low-caste party.

Khan, whose family had migrated to Pakistan from the town of Jullundur in India's Punjab state at Partition in 1947, also composed music for several foreign films including Hollywood's "Last Temptation of Christ".

The portly singer, whose quivering, metallic voice enthralled millions, had also announced plans to record an experimental music album with opera singer Luciano Pavarotti, but health problems hit his plans.
